{'Obama receives Netanyahu'}
The relationship between Obama and Netanyahu is not exactly friendly.
The two wanted to talk about the implementation of the international agreement and Tehran's destabilizing measures in the Middle East.
At the meeting it should also be about the conflict with the Palestinians and the proposed two-state solution.
The relationship between Obama and Netanyahu has been tense for years.
Washington criticized Israel's ongoing settlement construction and accused Netanyahu of lacking willingness in the peace process.
Through the deal promoted by Obama on Iran's nuclear program, the relationship between the two has further deteriorated.
In March, Netanyahu spoke at the US Congress at the invitation of the Republicans, delivering a controversial speech which was perceived in part as an affront to Obama.
The speech had not been agreed with Obama, he had rejected a meeting citing the then imminent election in Israel.
In an emergency call, Professor confesses to having shot his girlfriend.
In a distress call Professor Shannon Lamb told the police with a slightly shaky voice that he had shot his girlfriend and that the officers should come to his house.
Lamb stressed that his "sweet dog" was still alive and probably excited, and he said the deceased woman's family contacts could be found on the mobile phone.

Within the house, the officers found Amy Prentiss' corpse and a handwritten note scrawled on a white note block: "I'm so sorry, I wish I could take it back, I loved Amy and she's the only woman who ever loved me." This is according to authorities was in the letter, and it was signed by Lamb.

There was no indication that Lamb, who taught two online courses for Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, had already traveled 300 miles to the school grounds where, according to police, he shot and killed a popular history professor, Ethan Schmidt, at the door to his office.
Delta State University Police Chief Lynn Buford said university staff heard the shooting at 10:18 a.m.
He said that Lamb had made the fateful call sometime later.
By the end of the day, there was another death: Lamb took his own life when the police surrounded him.
One day after the shooting at the university that forced students and faculty to hide behind locked doors, authorities are still trying to figure out what motivated Lamb.
The details released by investigators at both ends of the state, as well as what students and staff who knew him said, helped to paint a picture of a talented but possibly difficult teacher.
Students said that they were looking forward to his lessons.
The police in Gautier, where Prentiss died, said he had no history of violence or criminal record.
Schmidt himself had mentioned Lamb in a book he wrote, in which he mentioned the "wonderful people" with whom he shared his academic life.
Both taught in the Department of Social Sciences and History, which has a faculty of 17 members, and many students attended courses from both.
At the same time, there were some tendencies towards problematic behaviours.
A student, Brandon Beavers, who praised the Lamb said he also seemed a bit excited and nervous, “as if something were wrong with him.”
Another student, Mikel Sykes, said that Lamm had told him that he had been dealing with stress at the end of the 2014-15 academic year.
Lamb had previously asked Delta State University for a leave of absence for health reasons, saying he had some kind of health problem.
This year he only taught two online courses.
The latest changes in the University's employment policy meant that Lamb's hard-earned PhD would not guarantee an automatic route to a job as Assistant Professor.
University President William LaForge said he knew nothing of a conflict between Lamb and Schmidt, but "of course there was something in Mr. Lamb's presentation."
Those are questions that Lamb cannot answer anymore.
After fleeing from the campus, the police later found Lamb's trail when he re-entered Mississippi from Arkansas.

Before he could be arrested, Lamb killed himself with a .38 caliber pistol in the backyard of a house about one mile south of his parents' home on the outskirts of Greenville, Mississippi, Washington County Coroner Methel Johnson said.
His car was still in the driveway.
It wasn't immediately clear why Lamm went to this house, but Johnson said she believe he knew the people who lived there.
Lamb grew up in the area.
Lamb began his work at the university in 2009, which had 3,500 students in a town of approximately 12,000 inhabitants and taught geography and pedagogy.
He graduated in spring with a degree in Pedagogy.
One of Lamb's long-time friends described him as intelligent, charismatic and funny.
Carla Hairston said she was 15 and Lamb was 20 when they met through mutual friends.
She and her friends were in high school, and he was the cool older guy who had been trying to teach her guitar for a few years.
He was the heartthrob at that time.
"All the girls melted when he was around," Hairston, now 40 and living in the Jackson suburbs of Brandon, said.
Lamb and Prentiss had evidently been together for some time.
In the emergency call Lamb said "I have killed my wife", but there was no record of a marriage.
They had a dog named Lightning who lived with them in the brick house bordering a bayou in Gautier.
The police said that the dog was okay.
The ex-husband of Prentiss, Shawn O'Steen, said they had been divorced 15 years ago but remained friends and had a daughter who was now 19 years old.
O'Steen said his daughter was completely devastated.
{She and her mother were absolutely best friends.
O'Steen said he had never met Lamb, but through his daughter Abigail he had heard that Lamb was interested in music and played blues.
Lamb met Prentiss when he and Abigail both performed at a summer fair three years ago.
Later they played together some gigs.
O'Steen said his daughter writes and sings her own music.
Prentiss was a nurse who worked online for various companies.

Mike Shaffer, a bartender and sometimes entertainment coordinator at The Julep Room, a dimly-lit bar near Gautier, said he last saw Lamb and Prentiss Night on the night of September 5th, after Lamb had finished his guitar and harmonica performance to a sparse crowd.
There were no signs that anything was wrong.
"Just a happy couple", he said.
We were tidying up and joking around with each other.
I think they both had a good sense of humor.
Schmidt, the deceased professor, headed the freshman seminar program and specialized in Native American and colonial history, said Don Allan Mitchell, an English professor at the school.
He was married and had three small children.
He studied at Emporia State University in Kansas and was president of his fraternity and the student council.
At the Delta State Campus in Cleveland, roughly 900 people, including faculty, staff, students, and members of the community, attended a candlelight memorial service on Tuesday night.
Schmidt's wife Liz and his brother Jeff Schmidt also took part in the vigil, while the university choir sang "Bright Morning Star" and "Amazing Grace".
Classes will resume on Wednesday.
"We are trying to persuade our students to return," said LaForge.
The crisis is over.
This is a day of healing.
Amy and Rogelio Solis reported from Cleveland, Mississippi.
Contributing to this report were Associated Press writers Emily Wagster Pettus in Greenville, Mississippi, and Rebecca Santana in New Orleans.

This story has been corrected to reflect that the police now say that Lamb made the 911 call after having shot Schmidt, and that in his 911 call, he referred to Prentiss as his wife, but there is no indication that the two ever married.
{Toys R Us plans to hire fewer workers for the Christmas season.}

Toys R Us says that it won't be hiring as many holiday season employees as last year, but the toy and baby products retailer says it will give its current employees and seasonal workers a chance to work more hours.
The company said it plans to hire 40,000 people in stores and distribution centers across the country. In the Christmas season of 2014, 45,000 personnel were hired.
Most jobs will be part-time jobs.
The company said it will start recruitment interviews this month and the number of employees increases from October to December.

While the holidays are still months away, the Christmas business is approaching and businesses are preparing to hire temporary workers to staff stores with employees who sell, ship and deliver products.
Michael J. Fox joked about his "date" with Princess Diana.
The premiere of "Back to the Future" was a major career moment for Michael J. Fox.
She was also remarkable for personal reasons.

"We were sitting in the theater waiting for the royals, and I noticed the seat next to me was empty, and it gradually dawned on me that Princess Diana would be sitting next to me," he said in a trailer for an upcoming documentary film "Back in Time".
The movie starts, and it occurs to me that I'm one simulated yawn and an arm's length away from going on a date with the Princess of Wales.
"Back in Time", a documentary about "Back to the Future", presents interviews with Fox, Lea Thompson and Christopher Lloyd, as well as with director Robert Zemeckis and producer Steven Spielberg.
"Back to the Future" had its premiere 30 years ago.
"It is really for me," said Spielberg, "undisputedly the greatest time-travel movie ever made."
"Back in Time" will be available on VOD, DVD, and in selected cinemas in October.
UN Chief says there is no military solution in Syria

Secretary General Ban Ki-moon says his response to Russia's increased military support for Syria is: "There is no military solution" to the nearly five-year-long conflict, and more weapons will only worsen violence and suffering for millions of people.
The UN Chief once again calls on all parties, including the divided UN Security Council, to unite and support integrative negotiations in order to find a political solution.

Ban said at a press conference Wednesday that he plans to meet with the foreign ministers of the five permanent member nations of the Council - U.S., Russia, China, Britain and France - on the sidelines of the General Assembly ministerial meeting later this month to discuss the situation in Syria.
He regretted that the splits within the Council and among the Syrian people and regional powers "make this situation insurmountable."
Ban urged the five permanent members to show the same solidarity and unity in tackling the crisis in Syria as they have demonstrated in reaching a nuclear deal with Iran.
8 Poll numbers showing that Donald Trump is to be taken seriously.
Some have tried to brand him a flop.
Others have dismissed him as a joke.
And some are waiting for a collapse.
But no matter how some Republicans try to drag Donald Trump down the ranks in the polls, it (still) hasn't worked.

Ten of the last eleven national polls have shown Donald Trump leading by double digits, and some are beginning to seriously question what it means for the chances of the real estate mogul's nomination.
Of course, it is still too early in the election period.
